levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Calculates areas of rectangles, triangles and parallelograms, and perimeters of simple shapes.
levels.example_task: Find the area and perimeter of a triangle with base 10 cm and height 6 cm, with sides 10, 8 and 7 cm.
levels.example_response: Area = ½ × 10 × 6 = 30 cm². Perimeter = 10 + 8 + 7 = 25 cm.
common_errors: Forgetting to halve for the triangle area
Using the slant height instead of the perpendicular height

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Calculates circumference and area of circles, and areas of trapezia and composite shapes.
levels.example_task: Find the area of a circle with diameter 14 cm.
levels.example_response: Radius = 7 cm. Area = π × 7² = 49π ≈ 153.9 cm².
common_errors: Using the diameter instead of the radius in the formula
Not squaring the radius

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Calculates arc lengths, sector areas and segment areas using the fraction of the full circle, giving exact answers in terms of π.
levels.example_task: Find the area of a sector with radius 10 cm and angle 72°.
levels.example_response: Fraction of circle = 72/360 = 1/5. Area = 1/5 × π × 100 = 20π cm².
common_errors: Using the arc length formula for area
Not simplifying the fraction 72/360

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves complex problems involving composite shapes, optimisation of area/perimeter, and proof of area relationships.
levels.example_task: A running track consists of a rectangle 100 m by w metres with semicircles of diameter w at each end. The total perimeter is 400 m. Find w and the area enclosed.
common_errors: Not including both semicircles in the perimeter
Using 2πr for both semicircles rather than just πw (which equals 2 × πw/2)

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Calculates volume of cuboids and surface area of simple shapes using formulae.
levels.example_task: Find the volume and surface area of a cuboid 5 cm × 3 cm × 4 cm.
levels.example_response: Volume = 5 × 3 × 4 = 60 cm³. Surface area = 2(15 + 20 + 12) = 2(47) = 94 cm².
common_errors: Confusing volume and surface area formulae
Missing a pair of faces in the surface area calculation

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Calculates volume and surface area of prisms and cylinders.
levels.example_task: Find the volume of a cylinder with radius 4 cm and height 9 cm.
common_errors: Computing πrh instead of πr²h
Not squaring the radius

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Calculates volume and surface area of pyramids, cones and spheres using given formulae, and solves problems involving composite solids.
levels.example_task: A hemisphere has radius 6 cm. Find its total surface area (curved surface + flat circle).
levels.example_response: Curved surface = ½ × 4πr² = 2π(36) = 72π. Flat circle = πr² = 36π. Total = 72π + 36π = 108π ≈ 339.3 cm².
common_errors: Forgetting the flat circular base
Using the full sphere surface area instead of half

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Solves problems involving frustums, optimisation of volume/surface area, and unit conversions (cm³ to litres).
levels.example_task: A cone of height 12 cm and radius 9 cm has the top 4 cm (by height) removed to form a frustum. Find the volume of the frustum.
levels.example_response: The small cone is similar to the large one with scale factor 4/12 = 1/3. Small radius = 9/3 = 3 cm. Large cone volume = ⅓π(81)(12) = 324π. Small cone volume = ⅓π(9)(4) = 12π. Frustum = 324π - 12π = 312π ≈ 980.2 cm³.
common_errors: Not using the similarity ratio to find the small cone's dimensions
Computing the frustum as a cylinder instead of a truncated cone

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: States Pythagoras' Theorem and uses it to find the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle.
levels.example_task: Find the hypotenuse of a right-angled triangle with legs 5 cm and 12 cm.
common_errors: Adding the sides without squaring
Not taking the square root at the end

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finds any side of a right-angled triangle and applies Pythagoras in coordinate geometry to find distances.
levels.example_task: Find the distance between points A(1, 3) and B(7, 11).
common_errors: Not squaring the differences
Adding instead of subtracting coordinates

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies Pythagoras in multi-step problems, determines whether triangles are right-angled, and works with exact (surd) answers.
levels.example_task: A rectangle has diagonal 15 cm and width 9 cm. Find the length and express as a surd if necessary.
levels.example_response: Length² = 15² - 9² = 225 - 81 = 144. Length = 12 cm. (No surd needed — it's a Pythagorean triple.)
common_errors: Adding instead of subtracting to find the shorter side
Not recognising 9, 12, 15 as a multiple of the 3, 4, 5 triple

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies Pythagoras' Theorem in 3D contexts and in combination with other geometric results.
levels.example_task: A room is 6 m long, 4 m wide and 3 m high. Find the length of the longest rod that can fit inside.
levels.example_response: The longest rod fits along the space diagonal. Face diagonal = √(6² + 4²) = √52. Space diagonal = √(52 + 9) = √61 ≈ 7.81 m.
common_errors: Finding only the face diagonal
Not applying Pythagoras twice (or using the 3D formula √(l²+w²+h²))

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can label the sides of a right-angled triangle (opposite, adjacent, hypotenuse) relative to a given angle and state SOHCAHTOA.
levels.example_task: In a right-angled triangle with angle θ, the opposite side is 6 cm and the hypotenuse is 10 cm. Which ratio gives sin θ?
levels.example_response: sin θ = opposite/hypotenuse = 6/10 = 0.6.
common_errors: Confusing opposite and adjacent
Using the wrong ratio

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses trigonometric ratios to find missing sides and angles in right-angled triangles.
levels.example_task: Find angle x in a right-angled triangle where the adjacent side is 8 cm and the hypotenuse is 12 cm.
common_errors: Using sin instead of cos
Not using the inverse function to find the angle

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies trigonometry in context including angles of elevation/depression and bearings, and knows exact values for 30°, 45°, 60°.
levels.example_task: From a point 50 m from the base of a tower, the angle of elevation to the top is 62°. Find the height of the tower.
common_errors: Using sin or cos instead of tan
Setting up the ratio with the wrong sides

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Applies trigonometry in multi-step 3D problems, proves trigonometric identities, and uses exact values fluently.
levels.example_task: Find the exact value of sin 60° × cos 30° + cos 60° × sin 30°.
levels.example_response: sin 60° = √3/2, cos 30° = √3/2, cos 60° = 1/2, sin 30° = 1/2. (√3/2)(√3/2) + (1/2)(1/2) = 3/4 + 1/4 = 1. This equals sin(60° + 30°) = sin 90° = 1, illustrating the addition formula.
common_errors: Not knowing the exact trigonometric values
Not recognising this as the sine addition formula

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Knows that the sine and cosine rules extend trigonometry to non-right-angled triangles, and can identify when to use each. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: When would you use the sine rule instead of SOHCAHTOA?
levels.example_response: The sine rule is used for non-right-angled triangles. You use it when you know a side and its opposite angle, plus one other piece of information. SOHCAHTOA only works for right-angled triangles.
common_errors: Trying to use SOHCAHTOA on a non-right-angled triangle
Not knowing the conditions for using each rule

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applies the sine rule to find unknown sides and angles in non-right-angled triangles. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: In triangle ABC: A = 40°, B = 70°, a = 8 cm. Find b.
common_errors: Not finding angle C first
Using the wrong pair of angle-side in the sine rule

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies the cosine rule to find unknown sides and angles, and uses the area formula ½ab sinC. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: In triangle PQR: p = 7, q = 9, R = 52°. Find r and the area.
common_errors: Using the wrong angle in the cosine rule
Forgetting the minus sign in a² = b² + c² - 2bc cosA

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Handles the ambiguous case of the sine rule, applies trigonometry in 3D, and solves complex multi-step problems. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: In triangle ABC: a = 10, b = 7, A = 40°. Find the two possible values of angle B (the ambiguous case).
levels.example_response: sinB/b = sinA/a. sinB = 7sin40°/10 = 7(0.6428)/10 = 0.4499. B = sin⁻¹(0.4499) = 26.7° or B = 180° - 26.7° = 153.3°. Check: 153.3° + 40° = 193.3° > 180° — impossible. Wait: A + B must be < 180°. 40° + 153.3° = 193.3° > 180°, so this is invalid. Only B = 26.7°. For the ambiguous case to yield two triangles, we need A + B₂ < 180°. Since 40° + 153.3° > 180°, there is only one triangle.
common_errors: Not checking that both values of B give a valid triangle
Not considering the obtuse angle possibility

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can identify the basic parts of a circle (radius, diameter, chord, tangent, arc, sector, segment) and state that a tangent is perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: Name the line that touches a circle at exactly one point and state its relationship to the radius.
levels.example_response: A tangent. It is perpendicular to the radius at the point of contact (they meet at 90°).
common_errors: Confusing tangent with chord
Not knowing the tangent-radius relationship

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applies the basic circle theorems: angle at centre = 2× angle at circumference; angles in a semicircle = 90°; angles in the same segment are equal. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: An arc AB subtends 130° at the centre O. What is the angle ∠ACB at the circumference?
levels.example_response: Angle at circumference = ½ × angle at centre = ½ × 130° = 65°.
common_errors: Doubling instead of halving
Not identifying which angle is at the centre and which is at the circumference

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies all standard circle theorems including opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral summing to 180°, the alternate segment theorem, and tangent properties. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: In a cyclic quadrilateral ABCD, ∠A = 85°. Find ∠C.
levels.example_response: Opposite angles of a cyclic quadrilateral sum to 180°. ∠C = 180° - 85° = 95°.
common_errors: Using 360° instead of 180° for opposite angles
Not checking that the quadrilateral is actually cyclic

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Proves circle theorems from first principles and applies them in multi-step geometric proofs. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: Prove that the angle in a semicircle is 90°.
levels.example_response: Let AB be a diameter of a circle with centre O. Let C be any point on the circumference. OA = OB = OC = r (radii). Triangle OAC is isosceles: ∠OCA = ∠OAC = α. Triangle OBC is isosceles: ∠OCB = ∠OBC = β. In triangle ABC: ∠A + ∠B + ∠C = 180°. α + β + (α + β) = 180°. 2(α + β) = 180°. α + β = 90°. So ∠ACB = 90°.
common_errors: Not identifying the isosceles triangles formed by radii
Not concluding that the angle at C is α + β

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands that congruent shapes are identical and similar shapes have the same shape but different sizes.
levels.example_task: Two triangles have angles 50°, 60°, 70°. One has sides 3, 4, 5 cm and the other has sides 6, 8, 10 cm. Are they congruent or similar?
levels.example_response: Similar (same angles, sides in ratio 1:2) but not congruent (different sizes).
common_errors: Confusing congruent with similar
Not checking the ratio of all corresponding sides

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Uses congruence criteria (SSS, SAS, ASA, RHS) to determine whether triangles are congruent and uses scale factors to find missing lengths in similar shapes.
levels.example_task: Two similar triangles have corresponding sides 5 cm and 8 cm. The smaller has perimeter 18 cm. Find the perimeter of the larger.
levels.example_response: Scale factor = 8/5 = 1.6. Perimeter of larger = 18 × 1.6 = 28.8 cm.
common_errors: Using the area scale factor instead of the linear one
Not identifying which sides are corresponding

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Applies similarity to find areas (k²) and volumes (k³) using the scale factor, and constructs congruence proofs.
levels.example_task: Two similar containers have heights 10 cm and 25 cm. The smaller holds 400 ml. Find the capacity of the larger.
levels.example_response: Scale factor k = 25/10 = 2.5. Volume scale factor = k³ = 15.625. Capacity = 400 × 15.625 = 6250 ml = 6.25 litres.
common_errors: Using k² instead of k³ for volume
Not cubing the linear scale factor

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Constructs formal congruence and similarity proofs, including proving that triangles within complex figures are similar or congruent.
levels.example_task: In triangle ABC, D is on BC such that ∠ADB = ∠ACB. Prove that triangles ABD and ACB are similar.
levels.example_response: In △ABD and △ACB: ∠ABD = ∠ACB (given: ∠ADB = ∠ACB... wait, let me reconsider). ∠ADB = ∠ACB (given). ∠ABD = ∠ABC (common angle at B). Therefore by AA similarity, △ABD ~ △ACB. This gives AB/AC = BD/BC = AD/AB.
common_errors: Not clearly identifying the two pairs of equal angles
Confusing which triangles are being compared

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Can identify and perform simple translations and reflections on a coordinate grid.
levels.example_task: Reflect triangle A in the line y = 0 (the x-axis).
levels.example_response: Each point (x, y) maps to (x, -y). So (2, 3) → (2, -3), (4, 1) → (4, -1), etc.
common_errors: Reflecting in the y-axis instead of the x-axis
Not changing the sign of the correct coordinate

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Describes and performs all four transformations fully, including rotations (with centre and angle) and enlargements (with centre and scale factor).
levels.example_task: Enlarge triangle with vertices (1,1), (3,1), (1,3) by scale factor 2, centre the origin.
levels.example_response: (1,1) → (2,2), (3,1) → (6,2), (1,3) → (2,6). Each coordinate is multiplied by 2.
common_errors: Enlarging from the wrong centre
Adding the scale factor instead of multiplying

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Works with negative and fractional scale factors, describes fully the single transformation equivalent to two combined transformations.
levels.example_task: Describe fully the single transformation equivalent to a reflection in y = 0 followed by a reflection in x = 0.
levels.example_response: (x, y) → (x, -y) → (-x, -y). This is equivalent to a rotation of 180° about the origin.
common_errors: Not tracking the coordinates through both transformations
Describing two transformations instead of finding the single equivalent

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Uses transformations in coordinate geometry proofs, identifies invariant points and lines, and analyses combined transformations algebraically.
levels.example_task: A shape undergoes the transformation (x,y) → (y,x). Describe this geometrically and find its invariant line.
levels.example_response: This swaps x and y coordinates, which is a reflection in the line y = x. Any point on y = x maps to itself, so y = x is the invariant line. For example: (3, 3) → (3, 3). Points off this line are reflected: (1, 4) → (4, 1).
common_errors: Not recognising the swap of coordinates as a reflection
Not identifying y = x as the mirror line

levels.label: emerging
levels.description: Understands that a vector has both magnitude and direction, and can represent a vector as a column vector or an arrow on a diagram. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: Write the vector from A(1, 2) to B(4, 6) as a column vector.
common_errors: Writing (1, 2) instead of (3, 4)
Computing B - A in the wrong order

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adds and subtracts vectors, multiplies by scalars, and represents these operations diagrammatically. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: If a = (2, 3) and b = (-1, 4), find 2a - b.
common_errors: Subtracting incorrectly: 4-(-1) = 3 instead of 5
Not multiplying both components by the scalar

levels.label: secure
levels.description: Uses vectors to describe positions and displacements, and understands that parallel vectors are scalar multiples of each other. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: OA = a and OB = b. M is the midpoint of AB. Find OM in terms of a and b.
levels.example_response: AB = b - a. AM = ½AB = ½(b - a). OM = OA + AM = a + ½(b - a) = a + ½b - ½a = ½a + ½b = ½(a + b).
common_errors: Writing OM = a + b (going all the way to B instead of the midpoint)
Not simplifying the expression

levels.label: mastery
levels.description: Constructs vector proofs to show points are collinear, lines are parallel, or shapes have specific properties. (Higher tier)
levels.example_task: OABC is a parallelogram. OA = a and OC = c. P divides AB in the ratio 1:2. Prove that O, P and the midpoint of BC are collinear.
levels.example_response: OB = a + c (parallelogram). AB = OB - OA = c. P divides AB in ratio 1:2: AP = ⅓c. OP = OA + AP = a + ⅓c. Midpoint M of BC: OM = OB + ½BC = (a + c) + ½(-c) ... BC = OC - OB = c - (a+c) = -a. So BM = ½(-a) = -½a. OM = OB + BM = a + c - ½a = ½a + c. Now check if OP is parallel to OM: OP = a + ⅓c. Is there a scalar k such that OP = kOM? a + ⅓c = k(½a + c). Comparing: k/2 = 1 gives k = 2, and k = 1/3 gives k = 1/3. Since 2 ≠ 1/3, they are not parallel in this general case. Let me reconsider the problem... The specific collinearity claim depends on exact point positions. Let me restate: P such that AP = ⅓AB means OP = a + ⅓c. For collinearity with O, we need OM = λOP for some scalar. ½a + c = λ(a + ⅓c). λ = ½ (from a) and λ = 3 (from c). These don't match, so O, P, M are not collinear with this particular ratio. The proof technique is correct: test whether one position vector is a scalar multiple of the other.
common_errors: Not expressing all vectors in terms of a and c from the origin
Confusing direction vectors with position vectors
